awd_titl_txt: Investigating Audience Engagement with Citizen Science
awd_abstract_narration: The Adler Planetarium, Johns Hopkins University, and Southern Illinois University-Edwardsville are investigating the potential of online citizen science projects to broaden the pool of volunteers who participate in analysis and investigation of digital data and to deepen volunteers' engagement in scientific inquiry. The Investigating Audience Engagement with Citizen Science project is administering surveys and conducting case studies to identify factors that lead volunteers to engage in the astronomy-focused Galaxy Zoo project and its Zooniverse extensions. The project is (1) identifying volunteers' motivations for joining and staying involved, (2) determining factors that influence volunteers' movement from lower to higher levels of involvement, and (3) designing features that influence volunteer involvement. The project's research findings will help informal science educators and scientists refine existing citizen science programs and develop new ones that maximize volunteer engagement, improve the user experience, and build a more scientifically literate public.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this research is to explore the motivations of volunteers participating in the Zooniverse suite of citizen science projects (www.zooniverse.org). This research builds on prior work into Galaxy Zoo, one of Zooniverse's component projects. In Galaxy Zoo, online volunteers classify galaxies by shape to benefit an astronomy research project. Interview and survey research of existing volunteers showed that their primary motivation was a desire to contribute to scientific research. That research had several limitations which we addressed in this project.

In this new research project, we look at several Zooniverse component projects in addition to Galaxy Zoo. Figure 1 shows three Zoos we study in this project: Galaxy Zoo 2, Moon Zoo, and Milky Way Project. Each project has its own data source and central task, and thus volunteers might participate in each Zoo as a result of vastly different motivations. In addition, volunteers participate in citizen science projects in many different ways, from short-time participation to long-term volunteer independent research taking place in project discussion forums. These different tasks could also result from a variety of motivations.

We began with a thorough literature review, leading to a model of motivations that may be in play at different levels of involvement and in different Zoos. We then designed an instrument to measure possible motivations, primarily by means of a 1-5 scale of agreement.

An important aspect of this research was to define a study sample. We did this by identifying three levels of engagement in citizen science. Initial users have completed only a few citizen science tasks, Sustained users have completed many, and Meta users participate in ways other than classifying. We created operational definitions of each user type, then selected samples of each and solicited survey responses from those users. In the end, we had responses from 723 Zooniverse volunteers.

Results show that there is indeed a clear difference between Initial users and other types of users on a variety of motivational constructs. However, Sustained and Meta users have largely similar motivations, in spite of their very different types of involvement in citizen science projects.

The results of this research will soon be published in the journals Science Education and Citizen Science: Theory and Practice, bringing the results to a new audience of education researchers and practitioners. The results are already being used by the Zooniverse project team to design future Zooniverse projects designed to appeal to the existing motivations of Zooniverse users.
